title: Post-Democracy Meets Post-Colony: London as a theory destination
desc: is Professor of Human Geography at University College London, and Visiting Professor at the African Centre for Cities, University of Cape Town. She has also worked at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban, the LSE (London) and the Open University. Her book,   (Routledge, 2006) developed a post-colonial critique of urban studies, arguing for urban theorising which draws on the experiences of a wider range of cities around the globe. This project has been taken forward in her call to reinvent comparative urbanism for global urban studies in her recent,   article in the International Journal of Urban and Regional Research, and  , in Progress in Human Geography. Current projects include exploring transnational aspects of Johannesburg and London's policy making processes and collaborative and community-based research comparing governance of large scale urban developments in London, Johannesburg and Shanghai (with Phil Harrison and Fulong Wu). She has also published extensively on the history and contemporary politics of South African cities, including   (Butterworth-Heinemann, 1996).
